A3.T2.caption: Table 2: Our focused hyperparameters for three privacy settings on EMNIST and CIFAR-10.
references:
Hyperparameters.
For each dataset, we uniformly set the global communication rounds Tğ‘‡T to 300, the total number of clients Nğ‘N to 100, and the sampled client number Kğ¾K to 10, resulting in a sampling rate pğ‘p of 0.1. Local training employs stochastic gradient descent (SGD) with 30 epochs (Eğ¸E), a learning rate Î·ğœ‚\eta of 0.1, and a batch size BğµB of 64. Other personalized hyperparameters: initial coefficient Î»ğœ†\lambda, common ratio Ï‘italic-Ï‘\vartheta, and interval Iğ¼I are listed in Table 2.

Time / h LDP-FedAvg PPSGD CENTAUR FedCEO
EMNIST 5.436 >> 24 >> 24 5.445

references: To validate the efficiency of our server-side low-rank proximal optimization, we conducted a comparative analysis of the runtime between our FedCEO and other methods in Table 3. We observe that the training efficiency of our method significantly surpasses PPSGD and CENTAUR, approaching the efficiency of LDP-FedAvg without any utility improvement.

references: To validate the effectiveness of our model in heterogeneous federated learning, we conduct experiments using an MLP as the local model on CIFAR-10 in Table 4. We report the testing accuracy for both iid and non-iid 111non-iid means the data among clients are not independent and identically distributed (iid). scenarios. It can be observed that our FedCEO maintains state-of-the-art performance. Additionally, in non-iid scenarios, we typically choose a larger Î»ğœ†\lambda to reduce the global semantic smoothness, preserving more personalized local information.
